verses.text: Hear my prayer, O LORD; let my cry for help come to you.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 102:title
rsbNotes.text: 102:title The title is unusual in that it gives, not a specific historical occasion, but the situation (affliction) in which the psalm finds appropriate use.

verses.text: Do not hide your face from me when I am in distress. Turn your ear to me; when I call, answer me quickly.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 102:2
rsbNotes.text: 102:2 hide your face. The psalmist wonders at the withdrawal of God’s friendship. He knows it is a sign of God’s wrath, since He promised to be with His obedient covenant people.

verses.text: For my days vanish like smoke; my bones burn like glowing embers.
My heart is blighted and withered like grass; I forget to eat my food.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 102:3
rsbNotes.text: 102:3 like a furnace. Points to the pain and suffering of life or more specifically to a raging fever.

verses.text: Because of my loud groaning I am reduced to skin and bones.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 102:5
rsbNotes.text: 102:5 bones cling to my flesh. His suffering is not only spiritual and psychological, but physical as well.

verses.text: I am like a desert owl, like an owl among the ruins.
I lie awake; I have become like a bird alone on a roof.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 102:6
rsbNotes.text: 102:6 like a desert owl of the wilderness. He is silent in his affliction, and without friends or supporters.

verses.text: All day long my enemies taunt me; those who rail against me use my name as a curse.
For I eat ashes as my food and mingle my drink with tears

rsbNotes.title: Ps 102:8
rsbNotes.text: 102:8 my enemies. As is typical in a lament, unnamed but real enemies are a source of distress to the psalmist. Because the enemies are unnamed, the psalm has timeless application to all generations.

verses.text: because of your great wrath, for you have taken me up and thrown me aside.
My days are like the evening shadow; I wither away like grass.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 102:10
rsbNotes.text: 102:10 your indignation and anger. The psalmist knows the ultimate cause of his suffering: God’s anger. He never disputes the justice of that anger, but he turns to God for relief.

verses.text: But you, O LORD, sit enthroned forever; your renown endures through all generations.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 102:12
rsbNotes.text: 102:12 forever. Over against the fragility of the psalmist’s life stands the constancy and eternity of the Lord.

verses.text: You will arise and have compassion on Zion, for it is time to show favor to her; the appointed time has come.
For her stones are dear to your servants; her very dust moves them to pity.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 102:13
rsbNotes.text:
102:13 arise. See notes Ps. 3:7 and 7:6.

on Zion. See Ps. 2:6; 3:3. The references to the destruction of Zion have led many commentators to place the psalm just after the Babylonian captivity.

verses.text: The nations will fear the name of the LORD, all the kings of the earth will revere your glory.
For the LORD will rebuild Zion and appear in his glory.
He will respond to the prayer of the destitute; he will not despise their plea.
Let this be written for a future generation, that a people not yet created may praise the LORD:
"The LORD looked down from his sanctuary on high, from heaven he viewed the earth,

rsbNotes.title: Ps 102:15
rsbNotes.text: 102:15 Nations will fear. As Jerusalem rises up from destruction, all who see it will praise the Lord.

verses.text: to hear the groans of the prisoners and release those condemned to death."
So the name of the LORD will be declared in Zion and his praise in Jerusalem
when the peoples and the kingdoms assemble to worship the LORD.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 102:20
rsbNotes.text: 102:20 to hear . . . to set free. Though God is above heaven, He enters the world to help the afflicted (9:18; 72:4 and notes).

verses.text: In the course of my life he broke my strength; he cut short my days.
So I said: "Do not take me away, O my God, in the midst of my days; your years go on through all generations.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 102:23
rsbNotes.text: 102:23 shortened my days. Through the sickness that now threatens the psalmist’s life.

verses.text: In the beginning you laid the foundations of the earth, and the heavens are the work of your hands.
They will perish, but you remain; they will all wear out like a garment. Like clothing you will change them and they will be discarded.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 102:25
rsbNotes.text: 102:25 Of old. God existed before His work of creation. The author of Hebrews applies vv. 25–27 to Christ (Heb. 1:10–12). There the argument is that however great the angels are considered, they are created, and not eternal. But Christ, the Second Person of the Trinity, exists through all eternity.

verses.text: But you remain the same, and your years will never end.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 102:27
rsbNotes.text: 102:27 you are the same. See “The Self-Existence of God” at 90:2.

verses.text: The children of your servants will live in your presence; their descendants will be established before you."

rsbNotes.title: Ps 102:28
rsbNotes.text: 102:28 The children of your servants. The poet’s hope is with the future generations. Though he suffers now in the present, he sees a brighter future.
